developer.name: Ululab
developer.description:
Slice Fractions: School Edition is a fun problem solving game that guides students to intuitively and effectively learn fractions through critical concepts. In this puzzling world, players must slice the right amount of ice and lava to clear the mammoth's path.

The game is the fruit of multiple years of research and development by Ululab with the help of math learning experts from the University of Quebec in Montreal (UQAM). It has a smooth progression designed for kids who are new to fractions or who have not yet understood its basic concepts. The environment is free of written instructions, which lets students dive into math reasoning without being obstructed by their literacy level.

headers.title: How to Play concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that establishes the basic game rules.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them about the role of different game elements. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: Bubble can hold objects and will pop when the player clicks on them.
Lava cancels out an equivalent amount of ice.
Chains are unbreakable.

headers.title: Split Groups concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that establishes how to divide a group of blocks into equal parts.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them about the role of ice columns. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: The number of ice columns dictates in how many groups you have to divide lava into.
An ice column that is lowered under the ground level indicates it received too much lava.

headers.title: Slice Shapes concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that establishes how to divide various shapes into equal parts.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them what slicing strategies seem to work. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: The number of ice columns dictates in how many groups you have to divide lava into.
An ice column that is lowered under the ground level indicates it received too much lava.
Lava blocks don't need to have the same shape represent equal quantities of lava.

headers.title: Shape Comparison concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that establishes how to compare parts to their whole.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them about the role of the white lines in the background. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: White lines represent the whole.
Smoke always hides lava behind it.
The symbol over smoke represents the lava part of the whole.

headers.title: Symbolic Numerator concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that introduces the numerical representation of fractions through symbols.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them about how the symbols over the smoke changed. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: The number of red blocks over the black line represent the number of lava parts behind the smoke.
The shapes drawn in white under the black line represent the whole these parts are compared to. They indicate how that whole is divided.

headers.title: Fractions Reading concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that introduces the numerical representation of fractions by comparing it to a symbolic representation.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them about the numbers that appeared on ice blocks. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: The number over the black line represents the number of parts of a divided whole.
The number under the black line represents in how many parts the whole was divided.

headers.title: Denominator concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that explores different ways to divide a whole into equal parts.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them why some ways of dividing blocks don't seem to work.
whatNow.summary: See if they can figure out by themselves that a whole needs to be split in equal parts to nullify shapes with fractions on them.

headers.title: Numerator concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that explores the impact different numerators have on the quantity of ice or lava.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them how changing the numerator changes the quantity of ice or lava. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: A fraction 1/B is the quantity formed by 1 part when a whole is partitioned into B equal parts.
A fraction A/B is the quantity formed by a parts of size 1/B.

headers.title: Pie Charts concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that explores ways to divide a shape that resembles a pie chart.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices.
whatNow.summary: Ask them about the different quantities they can make out of a circle.

headers.title: Size Comparison concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that explores how to compare fractions to each other to determine which represents the largest quantity and in what proportion.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them how they can determine the value of blocks that have a question mark on them. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: Doubling the numerator doubles the quantity (2/6 is two times bigger than 1/6).
Doubling the denominator divides the quantity in half (2/6 is half of 2/3).

headers.title: Equivalent Fractions (A) concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that have students manipulate fractions with different denominators to find out which ones are equivalent.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them why blocks that have different numbers on them can be of the same quantity.
whatNow.summary: See if they can figure out by themselves that 1/3 is the same as 2/6, because splitting a shape in 3 and taking one piece is the same as splitting it in 6 and taking 2 pieces.

headers.title: Equivalent Fractions (B) concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that offers different contexts in which to use equivalent fractions.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them why blocks that have different numbers on them can be of the same quantity.
whatNow.summary: See if they can figure out by themselves that 1/3 is the same as 2/6, because splitting a shape in 3 and taking one piece is the same as splitting it in 6 and taking 2 pieces.

headers.title: Fractions Ordering concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that asks players to place fractions in ascending order.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them what determines where an ice block should be. See if they can figure out by themselves that:
actionPoints: Fractions with the same denominator should be ordered by using the numerator in ascending order.
Fractions with the same numerator should be ordered by using the denominator in descending order.

headers.title: Question Marks concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that makes students deduct the value of the parts of a whole based on the information that is available to them.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them how they can deduct the quantity hidden behind question marks.
whatNow.summary: See if they can figure out by themselves that the total quantity of a whole shape is 1, therefore all parts in it need to add up to that total.

headers.title: Subtraction concept - retrying a level often
headers.description: A student repeated a particular level often in a series that explores the notion of subtracting quantities from 1.

whatNow.intro: Join the student during play, talking through his or her choices. Ask them how they can predict the quantity of ice or lava they will need to arrive at the desired fraction.
whatNow.summary: See if they can figure out by themselves by how much they should reduce ice or lava blocks before using them to nullify the blocks on the ground.

product.title: Product Description
product.header: Slice Fractions: School Edition - the award-winning game that will get your students excited about their next math discovery!
product.about: Slice Fractions: School Edition is a fun problem solving game that guides students to intuitively and effectively learn fractions through critical concepts. In this puzzling world, players must slice the right amount of ice and lava to clear the mammoth’s path. The game is the fruit of multiple years of research and development by Ululab with the help of math learning experts from the University of Quebec in Montreal (UQAM). It has a smooth progression designed for kids who are new to fractions or who have not yet understood its basic concepts. The environment is free of written instructions, which lets students dive into math reasoning without being obstructed by their literacy level.
curriculum: Addresses critical concepts, such as Part-whole partitioning, Numerator / Denominator notation, Fraction equivalence, Fraction ordering and Fraction subtraction.
Triggers specific common math misconceptions and causes players to reconsider what they thought they knew about fractions.
Students will let go of their fear of fractions and will instead gain interest in their complexity.

TEKS.category: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills: Math

list.name: TEKS.MATH.2.3
list.description: The student applies mathematical process standards to recognize and represent fractional units and communicates how they are used to name parts of a whole.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.A
list.description: Represent fractions greater than zero and less than or equal to one with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 using concrete objects and pictorial models, including strip diagrams and number lines.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.C
list.description: Explain that the unit fraction 1/b represents the quantity formed by one part of a whole that has been partitioned into b equal parts where b is a non-zero whole number.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.D
list.description: Compose and decompose a fraction a/b with a numerator greater than zero and less than or equal to b as a sum of parts 1/b.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.E
list.description: Solve problems involving partitioning an object or a set of objects among two or more recipients using pictorial representations of fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.F
list.description: Represent equivalent fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 6, and 8 using a variety of objects and pictorial models, including number lines.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.G
list.description: Explain that two fractions are equivalent if and only if they are both represented by the same point on the number line or represent the same portion of a same size whole for an area model.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.3.3.H
list.description: Compare two fractions having the same numerator or denominator in problems by reasoning about their sizes and justifying the conclusion using symbols, words, objects, and pictorial models.

list.name: TEKS.MATH.4.3.E
list.description: Represent and solve addition and subtraction of fractions with equal denominators using objects and pictorial models that build to the number line and properties of operations.

list.name: A preliminary efficacy study of Slice Fractions done by the University of Quebec in Montreal (UQAM) is showing promising results. UQAM professors are now performing a complete study in 2015 to understand how Slice Fractions changes students’ comprehension of important fractions concepts. The results will be posted here, so stay tuned!

list.review: Combine “Cut the Rope” style problem solving with a side scrolling venue that gets progressively harder, and you get the idea of Slice Fractions — an app that gently introduces some deep mathematical ideas, like equivalency, part-whole partitioning and numerator/denominator notation. Solving each level requires some higher order 2 and 3 step logical problem solving.

This app uses slicing mechanics similar to that of the mega-popular puzzler Cut the Rope, so you know kids will like to play it. The result is an engaging physics puzzler that feels like a game but which also hones kids' math skills in working with fractions.

Slice Fractions does a really great job of teaching without making it feel like a lesson, though it also dynamically gives hints if it senses you're stuck. The controls are straightforward and easy to use.

I am a special education teacher and I was looking for a fractions app for my students. This app is fabulous. I just finished playing it and wow it made me think. It is a combination of physics and fractions most appropriate for fourth or fifth grade students. I cannot wait to have my students try it.

Intelligent and well-designed application. Ideal to discover the step by step fraction concepts. Incorporates notions of physics and angles discreetly. Great graphics and sounds qualities. Kudos to the designers and educators who created this application!

I have been using this app as an added resource for teaching fractions to my special education students! It was so much fun they didn't even realize they were doing math! It is great for identifying, simplifying, adding, and subtracting fractions. Hope they add more levels soon!!
This game is amazing. I am a maths tutor and I've recommended it to all my clients. One boy I tutor is hooked on it. I will be looking out for other games by this developer
